study_design: Randomized field intervention dataset (control vs bright light/darkness); current paper reanalyzes by circadian adaptation status (adapted vs non-adapted) with pre/post 48h lab visits.
population_description: Healthy police officers on patrol working a fixed rotating roster including 7 consecutive night shifts (8-8.5h). Two participants completed both intervention and control conditions (counterbalanced), yielding 17 lab evaluations.
low_arousal_proxy_definition: Structural proxy: rotating shift work with 7 consecutive night shifts; circadian adaptation classified by salivary melatonin acrophase during scheduled daytime sleep in post-night-shift lab visit.
setting: field + lab (ambulatory night shifts + 48h lab visits before/after)
intervention_protocol: Light/darkness management during 7 consecutive night shifts (prior RCT): light exposure monitored with collar sensor; intervention participants wore orange-tinted goggles from sunrise to bedtime (and if awake during daytime sleep) to attenuate circadian-effective daylight; sleep periods scheduled in total darkness; in-lab light kept very dim (<10 lux).
comparator: Adapted vs non-adapted circadian phase after the 7-night sequence (classification based on melatonin acrophase timing).
outcome_measure: PVT median reaction speed (1/RT) (10-min), by time awake
outcome_timepoint: Post-night-shift lab visit (daytime sleep schedule), across wake period
effect_size_reported: Median reaction speed: no main effect of adaptation group (p=0.88); main effect of visit (p=0.012); main effect of time awake (p=0.036); 3-way interaction (group×visit×time-awake) p=0.046. During visit 2, adapted group faster than non-adapted after 8–14h awake (p≤0.045).
adherence_or_compliance: Light sensor worn during ambulatory period; orange-tinted goggles required for intervention group from sunrise to bedtime (per protocol).
notes: Analysis is primarily by adaptation status (not by randomized group); authors report adapted individuals show more stable performance across visits.

study_design: Counterbalanced within-subject crossover over 3 successive weeks (weekend sleep extension vs habitual weekend sleep).

study_design: non-randomized naturalistic ward comparison with partial within-subject crossover (nurses rotated wards every 6 weeks; fixed-effects regression; order not randomized)
population_description: Nurses/nurse assistants in an acute psychiatric inpatient unit (St. Olavs Hospital, Trondheim, Norway); shift workers (evening/night shifts).
low_arousal_proxy_definition: Structural proxy: shift work (evening/night shifts) with diary-rated sleepiness during shifts.
intervention_protocol: Blue-depleted light environment (BDLE) ward: from 18:30-07:00, light fixtures + incident light depleted of blue wavelengths (<530 nm); photopic lux similar to standard ward but melanopic lux lower; nurses could not manually change lighting; daytime lighting similar across wards.
comparator: Standard hospital light environment (STLE) ward; nurses rotated wards per preset schedule (6-week rotations).
outcome_measure: Subjective sleepiness (1-5) after each shift (work diary)
outcome_timepoint: Evening shifts during 14-day diary window (BDLE vs STLE; within-subject fixed-effects model)
effect_size_reported: Sleepiness higher in BDLE vs STLE during evening shifts: +17% (p=0.034; Cohen's d=0.49).
adherence_or_compliance: Work diary + sleep diary + actigraphy for 14 consecutive days toward end of each 6-week ward rotation; participation rate 29.1% of eligible staff.
notes: Primary effect observed is increased evening sleepiness in BDLE; no differences in sleep quantity/quality measures reported.
